title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text:
Over the past 20 to 30 years, the NFL has changed from run first play calling to pass first; at least that’s the general consensus. Many believe the running game has declined consistently, but others believe that the running game is evolving.
So which is it? I analyzed 20 years of NFL data (2004-2024) to find out if rushing is truly dying, or if it’s just evolving into something different.

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text: Everyone says the NFL run game is dying. Analysts claim teams are passing more than ever. But what does the data actually show? I analyzed 20 years of NFL play-by-play data to find out, and the results might surprise you. I analyzed 20 years of NFL data (2004-2024) to find out if rushing is truly dying, or if it’s just evolving into something different.

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text:
The Data


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(nflverse)

pbp_all <- load_pbp(2004:2024)

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text:
The First Decade: 2004-2014
Let’s start by looking at how NFL teams called plays during the 2004-2014 era.


Code
# Calculate run vs pass percentages for 2004-2014
play_trends_early <- pbp_early |>
  filter(!is.na(play_type), play_type %in% c("run", "pass")) |>
  group_by(season, play_type) |>
  summarise(plays = n(), .groups = "drop") |>
  group_by(season) |>
  mutate(pct = plays / sum(plays) * 100) |>
  ungroup()

# Create chart
ggplot(play_trends_early, aes(x = season, y = pct, color = play_type)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.5) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("run" = "#d00000", "pass" = "#0066cc"),
    labels = c("Rushing", "Passing")
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(35, 65)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2014, 2)) +
  labs(
    title = "NFL play calling: 2004-2014",
    subtitle = "Percentage of offensive plays by type",
    x = "",
    y = "Percentage of plays",
    color = "Play Type",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









During this decade, we can see that running plays made up roughly 43-45% of all offensive plays, while passing plays accounted for 55-57%. The balance stayed relatively stable across this period.

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving

The Recent Decade: 2015-2024
Now let’s see if that balance has shifted in the more recent era.


Code

    labels = c("Rushing", "Passing")

  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(35, 65)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2015, 2024, 2)) +
  labs(
    title = "NFL play calling: 2015-2024",
    subtitle = "Percentage of offensive plays by type",
    x = "",
    y = "Percentage of plays",
    color = "Play Type",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +

The shift becomes clear when comparing the two decades. In recent years, rushing plays have declined to around 40-42% of offensive plays, with passing increasing to 58-60%. That may seem like a small change, but across thousands of plays per season, it represents a significant strategic shift.

Two Decades of Play Calling: 2004-2024
Let’s look at how NFL offensive philosophy has changed over the past 20 years.

text:
Teams with Elite Rushing Production
Let’s compare how many teams hit the 1,700 rushing yard mark in each era.

Era 1: 2004-2014


Code
# Calculate team rushing yards for 2004-2014
team_rushing_early <- pbp_all |>
  filter(season >= 2004 & season <= 2014) |>
  filter(play_type == "run", !is.na(posteam)) |>
  group_by(season, posteam) |>
  summarise(
    rush_yards = sum(yards_gained, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

# Count teams with 1700+ yards per season

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text:
Elite Running Back Production
Has the number of elite running backs changed over the past 20 years?

1,000-Yard Rushers by Season


Code
player_rushing <- pbp_all |>
  filter(play_type == "run", !is.na(rusher_player_name), !is.na(yards_gained)) |>
  group_by(season, rusher_player_name) |>
  summarise(
    rushing_yards = sum(yards_gained, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

thousand_yard_rushers <- player_rushing |>
  filter(rushing_yards >= 1000) |>
  group_by(season) |>
  summarise(
    rushers_1000 = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

ggplot(thousand_yard_rushers, aes(x = season, y = rushers_1000)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 2, color = "#d00000") +
  geom_point(size = 4, color = "#d00000") +
  geom_text(
    aes(label = rushers_1000),
    vjust = -1.2,
    size = 3.5,
    fontface = "bold"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2024, 2)) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 35), breaks = seq(0, 35, 5)) +
  labs(
    title = "The Number of 1,000-Yard Rushers Has Fluctuated Over Time",
    subtitle = "Players with 1,000+ rushing yards per season, 2004-2024",
    x = "",
    y = "Number of 1,000-Yard Rushers",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 13, color = "gray40"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 11, face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 9, color = "gray50", hjust = 0)
  )











1,500-Yard Rushers by Season


Code
fifteen_hundred_rushers <- player_rushing |>
  filter(rushing_yards >= 1500) |>
  group_by(season) |>
  summarise(
    rushers_1500 = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

ggplot(fifteen_hundred_rushers, aes(x = season, y = rushers_1500)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 2, color = "#0066cc") +
  geom_point(size = 4, color = "#0066cc") +

    aes(label = rushers_1500),
    vjust = -1.2,
    size = 3.5,
    fontface = "bold"

  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 12), breaks = seq(0, 12, 2)) +
  labs(
    title = "Elite 1,500-Yard Rushers Have Become Rarer",
    subtitle = "Players with 1,500+ rushing yards per season, 2004-2024",
    x = "",
    y = "Number of 1,500-Yard Rushers",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 13, color = "gray40"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 11, face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 9, color = "gray50", hjust = 0)
  )









Looking at elite running back production, the data reveals something unexpected. From 2004 to 2010, the league averaged around 19 players with 1,000 rushing yards per season. But from 2011 to 2020, that number crashed and hit a low of just 8 in 2015. Elite 1,500-yard rushers became even rarer, dropping from 5-6 per year in the mid-2000s to just 1-2 in most recent seasons. However, since 2021, we’re seeing a rebound with 1700-1800 yard rushers returning. This suggests teams moved toward running back committees in the 2010s, spreading carries among multiple backs rather than feeding one workhorse. But here’s the real question: does any of this actually matter for winning games? If teams are running more now than they did 20 years ago, does that translate to more wins? Let’s find out.


Code
team_rush_pct_all <- pbp_all |>
  filter(!is.na(posteam), play_type %in% c("run", "pass")) |>
  group_by(season, posteam) |>
  summarise(
    rush_plays = sum(play_type == "run"),
    total_plays = n(),
    rush_pct = (rush_plays / total_plays) * 100,
    .groups = "drop"
  )

schedules_all <- load_schedules(2004:2024)

team_wins_all <- schedules_all |>
  mutate(
    home_win = if_else(home_score > away_score, 1, 0),
    away_win = if_else(away_score > home_score, 1, 0)
  ) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(home_team, away_team),
    names_to = "home_away",
    values_to = "team"
  ) |>
  mutate(
    win = if_else(home_away == "home_team", home_win, away_win)
  ) |>
  group_by(season, team) |>
  summarise(
    wins = sum(win, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

team_full_all <- team_rush_pct_all |>
  left_join(team_wins_all, by = c("season" = "season", "posteam" = "team"))

overall_corr <- cor(team_full_all$rush_pct, team_full_all$wins, use = "complete.obs")

ggplot(team_full_all, aes(x = rush_pct, y = wins)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.4, size = 2, color = "#d00000") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE, color = "#0066cc", linewidth = 2) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 17), breaks = seq(0, 17, 2)) +
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(30, 60)) +
  labs(
    title = "Running More Doesn't Guarantee More Wins",
    subtitle = paste0("All NFL teams, 2004-2024 seasons | Correlation: ", round(overall_corr, 3)),
    x = "Rush Percentage (% of plays that are rushes)",
    y = "Wins",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14, color = "gray40"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 11),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 10, color = "gray50", hjust = 0)
  )









The scatter plot reveals that rushing percentage has only a weak correlation (0.269) with winning. While there’s a slight upward trend, the massive spread of dots shows teams can win with any rushing attack. Some teams run 50%+ of the time and barely win 4 games. Others run less than 40% and win 14+ games. The data is clear, it’s not about running more, it’s about evolving and using the best strategy. So, is the NFL run game dying? Absolutely not. The data tells a story that contradicts the popular narrative. Despite what you hear from analysts and fans, teams are actually running the ball more than they did 20 years ago. The so called “death” of the run game never happened. What did happen was an evolution. The mid-2010s saw a dramatic shift toward running back committees, with elite 1,000-yard rushers dropping from 24 in 2006 to just 8 in 2015. Teams experimented with spreading carries among multiple backs rather than feeding a single workhorse. But since 2021, we’ve seen a return to feature backs. The other revealing finding is that running the ball more doesn’t have any correlation to winning more. This proves that it isn’t about volume, it’s about execution. Some of the league’s best teams run heavily. Others win by airing it out. What matters isn’t your philosophy, but how well you execute it.The NFL run game didn’t die. It adapted, evolved, and found its place in modern football. And the data proves it’s here to stay.

title: The Dan Campbell Effect
text:
In 2008, the Detroit Lions ended their season with an 0-16 record, making them the first team in NFL history to finish a season with no wins. This sounds bad, and it is, but Detroit fans were all but used to it. The Lions organization originated in 1930 and were a decently successful team up until the super bowl era in 1966. During the super bowl era, up until 2020, the Lions had won 332 times compared to their 439 losses, while only winning one playoff game. Due to this, they were known as one of the worst franchises in all of sports.
But something changed in 2021 when the Lions hired Dan Campbell at Head Coach. Coach Campbell instantly drew attention from the media as in his opening press conference he famously said “We’re gonna kick you in the teeth, all right? And when you punch us back, we’re gonna smile at you, and when you knock us down, we’re going to get up. And on the way up, we’re going to bite a kneecap off.” This gave Lions fans a spark and a new confidence had grown in Detroit.


Code
# Function to calculate offensive and defensive efficiency
calculate_efficiency <- function(schedules_data) {
  # Home team stats
  home_stats <- schedules_data |>
    select(season, team = home_team, 
           points_scored = home_score, 
           points_allowed = away_score) |>
    filter(!is.na(points_scored))
  
  # Away team stats
  away_stats <- schedules_data |>
    select(season, team = away_team, 
           points_scored = away_score, 
           points_allowed = home_score) |>
    filter(!is.na(points_scored))
  
  # Combine and calculate season averages
  combined_stats <- bind_rows(home_stats, away_stats) |>
    group_by(season, team) |>
    summarise(
      offensive_efficiency = mean(points_scored, na.rm = TRUE),
      points_allowed = mean(points_allowed, na.rm = TRUE),
      .groups = "drop"
    ) |>
    mutate(
      # Flip defensive efficiency: higher = better (inverse of points allowed)
      defensive_efficiency = max(points_allowed) - points_allowed + min(points_allowed)
    )
  
  return(combined_stats)
}

# Calculate for both eras
pre_campbell_stats <- calculate_efficiency(pre_campbell)
campbell_stats <- calculate_efficiency(campbell_era)

# Create highlight datasets for Lions
lions_pre <- pre_campbell_stats |> filter(team == "DET")
lions_campbell <- campbell_stats |> filter(team == "DET")

# Graph 1: Pre-Campbell Era (2000-2020)
ggplot() +
  geom_point(
    data = pre_campbell_stats,
    aes(x = offensive_efficiency, y = defensive_efficiency),
    color = "grey80",
    alpha = 0.3,
    size = 2
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = lions_pre,
    aes(x = offensive_efficiency, y = defensive_efficiency),
    color = "#0076B6",
    size = 3
  ) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data = lions_pre,
    aes(x = offensive_efficiency, y = defensive_efficiency, label = season),
    color = "#0076B6",
    size = 3,
    fontface = "bold",
    box.padding = 0.5,
    point.padding = 0.3
  ) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = mean(pre_campbell_stats$defensive_efficiency), 
             linetype = "dashed", color = "black", alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = mean(pre_campbell_stats$offensive_efficiency), 
             linetype = "dashed", color = "black", alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(
    title = "Detroit Lions: Two Decades of Mediocrity (2000-2020)",
    subtitle = "Lions offensive and defensive efficiency compared to NFL average. Top-right = elite teams, bottom-left = struggling teams.",
    x = "Offensive Efficiency (Points Scored Per Game)",
    y = "Defensive Efficiency (Inverse Points Allowed)",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | Higher on Y-axis = Better Defense"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 9),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text: Everyone says the NFL run game is dying. Analysts claim teams are passing more than ever. But what does the data actually show? I analyzed 20 years of NFL play-by-play data to find out, and the results might surprise you. I analyzed 20 years of NFL data (2004-2024) to find out if rushing is truly dying, or if it’s just evolving into something different.

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text:
The Data


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(nflverse)

pbp_all <- load_pbp(2004:2024)

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text:
Two Decades of Play Calling: 2004-2024
Let’s look at how NFL offensive philosophy has changed over the past 20 years.


Code
play_trends <- pbp_all |>
  filter(!is.na(play_type), play_type %in% c("run", "pass")) |>
  group_by(season, play_type) |>
  summarise(plays = n(), .groups = "drop") |>
  group_by(season) |>
  mutate(pct = plays / sum(plays) * 100) |>
  ungroup()

label_years <- c(2004, 2009, 2014, 2019, 2024)

play_trends_labeled <- play_trends |>
  mutate(
    label = if_else(season %in% label_years, paste0(round(pct, 1), "%"), "")
  )

ggplot(play_trends, aes(x = season, y = pct, color = play_type, group = play_type)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 2, alpha = 0.9) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_text(
    data = play_trends_labeled |> filter(label != ""),
    aes(label = label),
    vjust = -1.3,
    size = 4,
    fontface = "bold",
    show.legend = FALSE
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("pass" = "#d00000", "run" = "#0066cc"),
    labels = c("Rushing Plays", "Passing Plays")
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    limits = c(35, 65),
    breaks = seq(35, 65, 5),
    labels = paste0(seq(35, 65, 5), "%")
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = seq(2004, 2024, 2)
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "The NFL Has Gradually Shifted Back-and-Forth",
    subtitle = "Percentage of offensive plays by type, 2004-2024",
    x = "",
    y = "Percentage of Plays",
    color = "",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold", margin = margin(b = 5)),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14, color = "gray40", margin = margin(b = 15)),
    axis.title.y = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold", margin = margin(r = 10)),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 11),
    legend.position = "top",
    legend.text = element_text(size = 13, face = "bold"),
    legend.key.width = unit(1.5, "cm"),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 10, color = "gray50", hjust = 0, margin = margin(t = 15)),
    plot.margin = margin(20, 20, 20, 20)
  )









What I find interesting about this is that it is actually the opposite of what people think. Passing and Rushing have stayed stagnant for at least 20 years. So even though the running game hasn’t declined, why do people think it has. I decided to dive deeper into

title: The Running Game Isn’t Dying; It’s Evolving
text:
Elite Running Back Production
Has the number of elite running backs changed over the past 20 years?

1,000-Yard Rushers by Season


Code
player_rushing <- pbp_all |>
  filter(play_type == "run", !is.na(rusher_player_name), !is.na(yards_gained)) |>
  group_by(season, rusher_player_name) |>
  summarise(
    rushing_yards = sum(yards_gained, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

thousand_yard_rushers <- player_rushing |>
  filter(rushing_yards >= 1000) |>
  group_by(season) |>
  summarise(
    rushers_1000 = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

ggplot(thousand_yard_rushers, aes(x = season, y = rushers_1000)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 2, color = "#d00000") +
  geom_point(size = 4, color = "#d00000") +
  geom_text(
    aes(label = rushers_1000),
    vjust = -1.2,
    size = 3.5,
    fontface = "bold"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2024, 2)) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 35), breaks = seq(0, 35, 5)) +
  labs(
    title = "The Number of 1,000-Yard Rushers Has Fluctuated Over Time",
    subtitle = "Players with 1,000+ rushing yards per season, 2004-2024",
    x = "",
    y = "Number of 1,000-Yard Rushers",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 13, color = "gray40"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 11, face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 9, color = "gray50", hjust = 0)
  )











1,500-Yard Rushers by Season


Code
fifteen_hundred_rushers <- player_rushing |>
  filter(rushing_yards >= 1500) |>
  group_by(season) |>
  summarise(
    rushers_1500 = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

ggplot(fifteen_hundred_rushers, aes(x = season, y = rushers_1500)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 2, color = "#0066cc") +
  geom_point(size = 4, color = "#0066cc") +
  geom_text(
    aes(label = rushers_1500),
    vjust = -1.2,
    size = 3.5,
    fontface = "bold"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2024, 2)) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 12), breaks = seq(0, 12, 2)) +
  labs(
    title = "Elite 1,500-Yard Rushers Have Become Rarer",
    subtitle = "Players with 1,500+ rushing yards per season, 2004-2024",
    x = "",
    y = "Number of 1,500-Yard Rushers",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 13, color = "gray40"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 11, face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 9, color = "gray50", hjust = 0)
  )









Looking at elite running back production, the data reveals something unexpected. From 2004 to 2010, the league averaged around 19 players with 1,000 rushing yards per season. But from 2011 to 2020, that number crashed and hit a low of just 8 in 2015. Elite 1,500-yard rushers became even rarer, dropping from 5-6 per year in the mid-2000s to just 1-2 in most recent seasons. However, since 2021, we’re seeing a rebound with 1700-1800 yard rushers returning. This suggests teams moved toward running back committees in the 2010s, spreading carries among multiple backs rather than feeding one workhorse. But here’s the real question: does any of this actually matter for winning games? If teams are running more now than they did 20 years ago, does that translate to more wins? Let’s find out.


Code
team_rush_pct_all <- pbp_all |>
  filter(!is.na(posteam), play_type %in% c("run", "pass")) |>
  group_by(season, posteam) |>
  summarise(
    rush_plays = sum(play_type == "run"),
    total_plays = n(),
    rush_pct = (rush_plays / total_plays) * 100,
    .groups = "drop"
  )

schedules_all <- load_schedules(2004:2024)

team_wins_all <- schedules_all |>
  mutate(
    home_win = if_else(home_score > away_score, 1, 0),
    away_win = if_else(away_score > home_score, 1, 0)
  ) |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(home_team, away_team),
    names_to = "home_away",
    values_to = "team"
  ) |>
  mutate(
    win = if_else(home_away == "home_team", home_win, away_win)
  ) |>
  group_by(season, team) |>
  summarise(
    wins = sum(win, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

team_full_all <- team_rush_pct_all |>
  left_join(team_wins_all, by = c("season" = "season", "posteam" = "team"))

overall_corr <- cor(team_full_all$rush_pct, team_full_all$wins, use = "complete.obs")

ggplot(team_full_all, aes(x = rush_pct, y = wins)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.4, size = 2, color = "#d00000") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE, color = "#0066cc", linewidth = 2) +
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 17), breaks = seq(0, 17, 2)) +
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(30, 60)) +
  labs(
    title = "Running More Doesn't Guarantee More Wins",
    subtitle = paste0("All NFL teams, 2004-2024 seasons | Correlation: ", round(overall_corr, 3)),
    x = "Rush Percentage (% of plays that are rushes)",
    y = "Wins",
    caption = "Source: nflverse | By Joel Hammond"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14, color = "gray40"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12, face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 11),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 10, color = "gray50", hjust = 0)
  )









The scatter plot reveals that rushing percentage has only a weak correlation (0.269) with winning. While there’s a slight upward trend, the massive spread of dots shows teams can win with any rushing attack. Some teams run 50%+ of the time and barely win 4 games. Others run less than 40% and win 14+ games. The data is clear, it’s not about running more, it’s about evolving and using the best strategy. So, is the NFL run game dying? Absolutely not. The data tells a story that contradicts the popular narrative. Despite what you hear from analysts and fans, teams are actually running the ball more than they did 20 years ago. The so called “death” of the run game never happened. What did happen was an evolution. The mid-2010s saw a dramatic shift toward running back committees, with elite 1,000-yard rushers dropping from 24 in 2006 to just 8 in 2015. Teams experimented with spreading carries among multiple backs rather than feeding a single workhorse. But since 2021, we’ve seen a return to feature backs. The other revealing finding is that running the ball more doesn’t have any correlation to winning more. This proves that it isn’t about volume, it’s about execution. Some of the league’s best teams run heavily. Others win by airing it out. What matters isn’t your philosophy, but how well you execute it.The NFL run game didn’t die. It adapted, evolved, and found its place in modern football. And the data proves it’s here to stay.
